awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Measurement and Analysis of Nocturnal Mesoscale Convective Systems and Their Stable Boundary Layer Environment During PECAN
awd_abstract_narration:
The Plains Elevated Convection At Night (PECAN) experiment will investigate the evolution of nocturnal mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) and convection and their interactions with the evolving nocturnal stable boundary layer (SBL) environment. This proposal addresses two primary goals of PECAN: 1) To characterize the transition from surface-based to elevated nocturnal MCS structure and the interaction of cold pools generated by MCSs with the nocturnal SBL, and 2) to determine how the organization and evolution of surface-based and elevated MCSs are influenced by the stable boundary layer and the vertical profile of wind and stability above the nocturnal low-level jet (NLLJ). To rectify the present paucity of detailed, integrated observations of nocturnal MCSs and their SBL environments, the project will observe nocturnal MCSs and convection with mobile ground-based radars, mobile sounding systems, and mobile mesonets in concert with other ground-based and airborne observing platforms during PECAN. Multi-radar syntheses, data assimilation, and modeling will provide the integrated analyses of these combined observations to evaluate the detailed internal structure of nocturnal MCSs and the impact of static stability, pre-existing boundaries, and wind shear on nocturnal MCS evolution processes.

Intellectual Merit:
This project emphasizes the tightly coordinated observation of nocturnal MCSs and their SBL environments with an array of multiple mobile Doppler and dual-polarimetric radars in conjunction with mobile soundings and surface in situ observing systems. These observations will be integrated to obtain 3-D airflow syntheses, precipitation fields, and thermal structure of MCSs and newly initiated convection and their environments. Mobile radars are essential as they can provide enhanced temporal and spatial resolution and low-level observations over any area within the PECAN domain. C-band radars, with their ability to both penetrate heavy precipitation and sense clear-air inflow, are required. The mobile C- and X-band dual-polarimetric radars will provide microphysical information beyond the typical operating ranges and below base-scan altitudes of the polarimetric WSR-88D radars. The mobile sounding and surface observations complement the radar wind measurements by providing unique buoyancy and shear profiles both within and outside of precipitation, thus resolving internal MCS dynamics and characterizing the SBL environment that interacts with the MCSs. These data, in combination with other PECAN data from fixed and mobile ground-based radar, profilers, mesonets, and aircraft, are essential for interpreting nocturnal MCS evolution with respect to in situ environmental conditions and for providing input and validation of cloud dynamical-microphysical model simulations of MCSs. The scientific objectives of this project are to: (i) document the internal structure and evolution of nocturnal MCSs and convection; (ii) establish the environmental ingredients and related physical mechanisms that control nocturnal MCS evolution; and (iii) test hypotheses concerning MCS dynamical microphysical forcing and MCS-environment interactions within detailed cloud-resolving models. The research conducted here will advance fundamental knowledge of the internal MCS dynamics and interactions with the SBL and will enable better representations of both within cloud-resolving models.

Broader Impacts:
Characterizing the morphology of nocturnal MCSs and the vertical profiles of temperature, humidity and winds ahead of and near the convective region in the cold pool are essential to helping improve the specificity and accuracy of diagnoses and short-term predictions of the geographical extent and duration of severe weather, heavy rainfall, flash flooding, and aircraft icing conditions. Additionally, these PECAN field observations will be essential for refining data assimilation systems and improving future operational numerical predictions of nocturnal MCSs and their SBL environments. The datasets collected here will also be used in university classes through graduate level. Several undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the execution of a large atmospheric field campaign by being integrated into the data collection and post-field phase analysis. Lastly, the data collected here will be made available to other NSF and NOAA investigators identified as part of the PECAN project.

por.por_cntn:
It has long been known that the central United States has a nocturnal maximum in summertime precipitation, and that this maximum primarily reflects recurring, long-lived, large groups of thunderstorms known as mesoscale convective systems (MCSs). In addition to their integrated seasonal rainfall, nocturnal MCSs produce severe, long-lived convective wind storms as well as a large fraction of local warm season extreme precipitation events (e.g., flash floods). Given nocturnal MCS impacts on society as well as their relatively poor prediction compared to daytime severe local storms, the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN, summer 2015) field project was designed to explain the evolution and structures of nocturnal MCSs and relate them to specific mechanisms and environmental ingredients.

 

We were actively involved via both steering committee and science team participation in the planning, field preparations, and execution of the PECAN project. This effort led to a peer-reviewed overview journal article describing the project. We developed a GIS-based virtual database of over 12,000 sites across the southern and central US Great Plains region, that assisted field project coordinators in deploying mobile radars to locations with minimal terrain blockage.  We contributed one airborne radar and three mobile ground-based radars to map airflow and precipitation intensity within at least a dozen nocturnal MCS cases. We also deployed two mobile sounding (weather balloon) systems as well as surface-based mobile mesonet observations in each MCS.  These collectively enabled subsequent studies of nocturnal MCS morphology and dynamics, the evolution of low-level stability and wind profiles, and their influence on the initiation and maintenance of MCSs overnight.

 

We conducted a longitudinal study of the full suite of PECAN sounding data and found several novel aspects of nocturnal MCS near-inflow and internal environments.  This study led to a peer-reviewed journal article.   In some cases the nocturnally-cooled pre-convective environment evolved quite rapidly, especially when the primary source of instability was elevated.  Contrary to expectations, in other cases the nocturnal boundary layer preserved a structure very reminiscent of what is observed during the afternoon period. These findings suggest that many PECAN MCSs are not especially different from well-understood afternoon MCSs.

 

We conducted detailed multi-radar analyses of the airflow and precipitation fields and radar-based retrievals of temperature and hydrometeor fields in two of the most intense nocturnal MCSs from PECAN. This study led to a peer-reviewed journal article and a portion of the aforementioned overview journal article describing the project.  The unprecedented 7-radar analyses mapped the MCSs' core regions spanning 2-3-hour periods of MCS evolution, while retrieved surface cold pool temperatures agreed with independent surface temperature measurements. The first wind damage report in one of the MCSs coincided with an intense horizontal rotor circulation producing low-level radar-derived wind speeds significantly exceeding severe limits.  The strongest near-surface winds associated with the latter MCS were located in cold, precipitation-laden near-surface outflow just downstream from a strong downdraft which accelerated the horizontal winds to severe-intensity speeds.  This finding provides forecasters with conceptual process understanding to improve short-range forecasts of severe wind potential based on real-time operational nocturnal MCS radar observations.

 

We performed realistic simulations of two of the most intense MCSs from PECAN, as well as an idealized simulation of one of those MCSs, to isolate the dynamical origins of severe near-surface straight-line winds and low-level rotation in nocturnal MCSs.  These studies led to 2 peer-reviewed journal articles and two PhD dissertations.  Severe near-surface winds in all MCS simulations were accelerated by descending cold, precipitation-laden outflow air in downdrafts, downward transport of stronger winds aloft, and horizontally decreasing air pressure in the downdraft exit regions. The latter pressure accelerations were essential for producing significantly severe near-surface winds over time periods as brief as ~ 5 min following the airflow motion. The origins of low-level mesocyclonic rotation were attributed to the generation and transport of airflow rotation about a horizontal axis that was subsequently tilted into rotation about a vertical axis and intensified by entry into a low-level updraft in the MCS's leading deep convective updraft line. This new process understanding can help forecasters assess the higher potential for nocturnal MCSs to produce localized severe near-surface winds and potentially tornadic rotations in environments that have previously been thought of as rather benign.

 

We conducted an analysis of single-radar air velocity and light precipitation intensity in a horizontally stratified thunderstorm anvil cloud that subsequently initiated an MCS. This led to a peer-reviewed journal article. We found that sub-anvil sublimative cooling of falling snow particles in dry air produces downdrafts that reach ground level.  These surface-based, sub-anvil downdrafts subsequently produce surface outflows and adjacent updrafts, that in turn lift moist ambient air to initiate a line of new thunderstorms and form the MCS.  This new process understanding informs the development of more accurate numerical storm forecast models and improved human forecasts of MCS formation.
